chapter.title: Build Job Constraints
chapter.para: Build job constraints can define requirements for the hardware or software of the build host. Constraints can be defined per package or for repositories.
The build constraints for an entire project or specific repositories is part of the project config. For each constraint, it contains a line
The selector is a colon-separated list.
The build constraints for a package are part of the package sources, as a _constraints XML source file (validated on submission). The _constraints source file can contain the values listed below.
NOTE: If no build host meets the constraints, the package will stay in state "scheduled" and never be dispatched.

sect1.para: The hostlabel is any string which can be assigned to build hosts when starting the bs_worker process. It can be used to run on specific hosts, which may be used for running benchmarks in a reproducible way. This constraint can also be defined as a negative definition using the exclude=true attribute. However, the hostlabel is always specific to one OBS instance. You should avoid it as much as possible, since building with this constraint in another instance is usually not possible. Use any of the other constraints if possible.

Defines the sandbox which is used for the build job. Sandboxes are chroot, Xen or KVM environments. There is also the virtual secure sandbox, which allows building on Xen or KVM. This constraints may also be defined as a negative definition via the exclude=true attribute.

sect2.title: version
sect2.para: To require a specific Linux kernel version.
A specific kernel flavor like default or smp (from kernel packages kernel-default or kernel-smp).

sect1.para: To require hardware or build instance features.

sect2.para: To require a specific CPU feature.

sect3.para: CPU features which are provided by the hardware. On Linux they can be found in /proc/cpuinfo. The flag element may be used multiple times to require multiple CPU features.
sect3.screen: Constraint: hardware:cpu:flag mmx Constraint: hardware:cpu:flag sse2
sect3.para: A special flag is 'EL0', which can get added on specific armv8l systems. It is telling that it the hardware is supporting only execption level 0. This basically means no vm or kernel in 32bit is supported, but user land is supported. This flag can be used to block builds on such hardware, if no 64bit kernel is available for certain projects:

sect2.para: To require a minimal number of processors for the build job.

sect3.para: To require a minimal size of the disk.
To require a minimal memory size including swap space.
To require a minimal memory size. Swap space is not taken into account here.

sect1.title: Constraint Handling
sect1.para: The constraint handling depends on what is met by the restrictions. The handling starts when there is no worker to fulfill the constraints.

sect2.title: More than half of the workers satisfy the constraints
sect2.para: The job will just stay in state scheduled and no further notification is set.

sect2.title: Less than Half of the Workers Satisfy the Constraints
sect2.para: The job will stay in state scheduled and the dispatch details are set to tell the user that this job can take a long time to be built. This will be shown in the Web UI on mouse over and the scheduled state will be highlighted as well.
The (4 down) means that 4 of the 4 compliant workers are down and that someone should have a look.

sect2.title: No Workers Satisfy the Constraints
sect2.para: If no worker can handle the constraints defined by the package or project the build job fails. There is also a hint in the build log what has failed.

sect1.title: Checking Constraints with &osccmd;
sect1.para: You can check the constraints of a project / package with the osc tool. You have to be in an osc working directory.
Either you give a repository and an arch or osc will check the constraints for all repository / arch pairs for the package. A few examples:
sect1.screen: # osc checkconstraints Repository Arch Worker ---------- ---- ------ openSUSE_Leap_42.2 x86_64 1 openSUSE_Leap_42.1 x86_64 1
sect1.para: If no file is given it takes the local _constraints file. If this file does not exist or the --ignore-file switch is set only the project constraints are used.
sect1.screen: # osc checkconstraints openSUSE_Leap_42.1 x86_64 Worker ------ x86_64:worker:1 x86_64:worker:2
sect1.para: If a repository and an arch is given a list of compliant workers is returned.
Another command to verify a worker and display the worker information is osc workerinfo.
It returns the information of the desired worker.
